Title: Area-to-point prediction under boundary conditions
Affiliations: Department of Geography, University at Buffalo, The State University of New York, Buffalo, NY 14261-0055, United States; Department of Geography, University of California Santa Barbara, Ellison Hall, Santa Barbara, CA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Yoo, E.H., Department of Geography, University at Buffalo, The State University of New York, Buffalo, NY 14261-0055, United States; Kyriakidis, P.C., Department of Geography, University of California Santa Barbara, Ellison Hall, Santa Barbara, CA, United States
Abstract: This article proposes a geostatistical solution for area-to-point spatial prediction (downscaling) taking into account boundary effects. Such effects are often poorly considered in downscaling, even though they often have significant impact on the results. The geostatistical approach proposed in this article considers two types of boundary conditions (BC), that is, a Dirichlet-type condition and a Neumann-type condition, while satisfying several critical issues in downscaling: the coherence of predictions, the explicit consideration of support differences, and the assessment of uncertainty regarding the point predictions. An updating algorithm is used to reduce the computational cost of area-to-point prediction under a given BC. In a case study, area-to-point prediction under a Dirichlet-type BC and a Neumann-type BC is illustrated using simulated data, and the resulting predictions and error variances are compared with those obtained without considering such conditions. Title: USING QUADTREES TO SMOOTH IMAGES.
Source title: IEEE Transactions on Systems, Man and Cybernetics
Abstract: Three methods for smoothing images are presented. All three use variable numbers of picture points over which the smoothing functions are defined. The first method examines the histogram of a neighborhood of each point. The subset of gray values most similar to that of the point is used in calculating the smoothing functions. The other two methods use quadtree approximations to smooth the image. One of these uses the sizes of the leaves in the quadtree to determine neighborhood sizes over which to apply a smoothing function, while the other refines the gross smoothing defined by the quadtree. All the methods perform fairly well, but the quadtree methods are particularly attractive because of the information about region sizes and homogeneity provided by the quadtree structure.
Index Keywords: Image processing
Correspondence Address: Ranade, Sanjay

Title: An application of economic interaction models to the analysis of spatial effects of economic intergration.
Abstract: Classical partial-equilibrium analysis of integration in a spaceless world is extended by introducing the spatial dimension. However, this model, due to its unrealistic homogeneity assumptions, generates an extremely rigid response by the endogenous variables to tariff reductions. Two approaches are discussed for introducing heterogenity: a deterministic utility-maximization and a probabilistic choice approach. Both lead to a substitution of the transportation model, which is embedded in the homogeneous model, by a trade-distibution model of the gravity type. In this framework regional shadow prices are derived which play the same role as those of the transportation model and can be used for measuring the impact of economic intergration on regional access to input and output markets. Finally a family of elastically constrained gravity models is considered, which are derived by price-elastic supply and demand with the trade-distribution model. These can be empirically applied for calculating simultaneously the effects of tariff reductions on regional supply and demand as well as on interregional trade. - Author
Index Keywords: gravity type; interregional trade; model; regional shadow prices; supply and demand; tariff reductions; trade distribution

Title: Review Article: National Geocoding
Source title: Annals of the Association of American Geographers
Affiliations: Urban Systems Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States
Authors with affiliations: Werner, P.A., Urban Systems Laboratory, Massachusetts Institute of Technology, Cambridge, MA 02139, United States
Abstract: National geocoding has lagged far behind urban geocoding. Semantic confusion is endemic to both, but macrolevel geocoding has more diversity and specialization than microlevel geocoding because of the lack of geographic building block units for national geocoding. National systems can be classified by principal application into four categories, but information exchange, even among those of the same class, is not necessarily possible. A converter has been designed to permit association of variously coded data sets based on the county as a common unit, and some standardization and convertibility among systems has been implemented, key words: Area systems, County, Geocoding converter, Geographic coding, National geographic base files. © 1974, Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. Title: ESTIMATING MARKOV TRANSITION PROBABILITIES FROM MICRO-UNIT DATA.
Abstract: The standard method of deriving maximum-likelihood estimates for transition probability matrices is outlined. Statistical tests for determining the Markov property, the specific order of a chain and the homogeneity of a set of matrices are applied to data relating to manufacturing establishments. Refinements to the maximum-likelihood procedure are examined in the context of fractional disaggregation of long-period matrices and in the framework of fitting smoothing surfaces to observed transition probabilities.
Index Keywords: Probability

Title: Perimetric charts in aequivalent projection allowing a planimetric determination of the extension of the visual field
Affiliations: Zeist, Netherlands
Abstract: After a survey of the usual methods of projection of the visual field, a perimetric chart in aequivalent projection is described which allows a planimetries] determination of the area of the field of vision on the visual sphere. The number C is introduced for the relative part of the visual field (and of the retinal surface approximately) which is still active. C = S/S0 S = surface of visual field of patient, S0= surface of normal visual field. Furlhermore, an attempt is described to construct a perimetric chart in which the area of the field is a measure of the active number of pericipient units. It is shown, however, that such a chart has no practical clinical value. © 1947 S. Karger AG, Basel.

Title: Cartographic methods for determining the qibla
Affiliations: Department of Geosciences, Oregon State University, Corvallis, OR, 97331, United States
Authors with affiliations: Kimerling, A.J., Department of Geosciences, Oregon State University, Corvallis, OR, 97331, United States
Abstract: Islam is an important topic in human and regional geography instruction, and major textbooks include maps showing Islam's core and rapid expansion diffusion, along with the number of pilgrims to Mecca from different countries. Determining the qibla, the sacred direction for daily prayer, and the distance to Mecca are additional topics that link human geography, Islamic mathematical geography, and modern geographic information science. Recently discovered Persian instruments used a retro-azimuthal map projection devised by medieval Muslim mathematicians to compute the qibla and distance to Mecca from anywhere within the seventeenth century realm of Islam. Modern global maps that allow the qibla and distance to Mecca to be determined from all populated areas on earth are added to the Persian instruments. © 2002 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.
Author Keywords: Geography of religion; Islam; Mosque alignment; Pilgrimage to Mecca; Qibla

Title: Structural analysis of social data: a guide to Ho's Galois lattice approach and a partial respecification of Q-analysis.
Affiliations: Sch. Geog., Leeds Univ., Leeds LS2 9JT, UK., United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Macgill, S.M., Sch. Geog., Leeds Univ., Leeds LS2 9JT, UK., United Kingdom
Abstract: Provides a basis for respecifying Atkin's Q-analysis in a way that is believed to be more powerful, more economical, and accessible to a wider audience. Concepts of traffic and eccentricity are reexamined, but more generally, the suggested respecification may enhance the utility of Q-analysis and broaden its applicability, while remaining true to its underlying ethos.-Author

Title: Data display techniques for transportation analysis and planning: An investigation of three computer-produced graphics
Affiliations: Urban Transportation Program, Departments of Civil Engineering and Urban Planning, University of Washington, Seattle, Washington, 98195, United States
Authors with affiliations: Noguchi, T., Urban Transportation Program, Departments of Civil Engineering and Urban Planning, University of Washington, Seattle, Washington, 98195, United States; Schneider, J.B., Urban Transportation Program, Departments of Civil Engineering and Urban Planning, University of Washington, Seattle, Washington, 98195, United States
Abstract: Graphics are a powerful but often costly means of communication. Computer-drawn graphics offer a new and relatively inexpensive way to assist the communication of complex technical information to both planners and non-technical people whose full potential is now beginning to be realized. This paper discusses the utility of graphics and introduces three computer-drawn graphic techniques which may be useful, both for analysis and presentation of results, in the transportation planning process. CENVUE(S) produces a three-dimensional, perspective-view map, on which virtually any type of transportation data or performance indicator can be displayed. VAP is designed to display origin-destination travel patterns in any region. TDN transforms a physical-distance network into a time-distance network so that effects of different speeds in the transportation network can be readily seen. The cost-effectiveness of each technique is briefly discussed and some recommendations for evaluating computer graphics techniques are provided to aid the user in further assessing their utility in the transportation planning process. © 1977 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC. All rights reserved.

Title: On projections for maps applying to a very large extent of the Earth's Surface
A graphical introduction to survey adjustment
Abstract: It is important that cartographers, and others who use geographic information, understand the procedures used to adjust empirical measurements made for the purpose of specifying locations. Two new graphical interpretations of reconciling distance or directional observations are presented in this paper. These graphics are consistent with standard practice, but treat the problems in a somewhat more general, non-mathematical manner, facilitating understanding. An example is given using driving distances to obtain a map configuration for points in the United States.
Index Keywords: cartography; error; land survey; survey adjustment

Affiliations: Department of Geography, Moscow State University, Moscow, 119899, Russian Federation
Authors with affiliations: Tikunov, V.S., Department of Geography, Moscow State University, Moscow, 119899, Russian Federation
Abstract: The author gives a brief outline of the history of map transformation techniques. Various methods of compiling linear and areal anamorphoses, such as manual, mechanical and electric analogies techniques, along with the employment of photographic and digital processing, are discussed. A new technique of constructing transformed maps is proposed and possible applications of such maps in geographic research are presented. © 1988 Taylor & Francis Group, LLC.

Title: ANIMATING QUANTITATIVE MAPS WITH CELLULAR AUTOMATA.
Authors with affiliations: Appel, A.; Evangelisti, C.J.; Stein, A.J.
Abstract: A quantitative map or cartogram is a distortion of a geographical map such that the areas are proportional to some statistic. Cellular automata enable the rapid design of these maps. More important, the cellular automata animate the process so geographic association with the final form is easier and more obvious. Maps are considered where areas are proportional to some statistic, such as population or percent of area that is urban, etc. These maps are usually prepared by hand. The method described is an effort at automating the generation and animation of such maps.
Index Keywords: Automata theory; MAPS AND MAPPING
Correspondence Address: Appel, A.

Authors: Eastman J.R., Nelson W., Shields G.
Title: Production considerations in isodensity mapping.
Affiliations: Boston Univ, Boston, Mass, USA., United States
Authors with affiliations: Eastman, J.R., Boston Univ, Boston, Mass, USA., United States; Nelson, W., Boston Univ, Boston, Mass, USA., United States; Shields, G., Boston Univ, Boston, Mass, USA., United States
Abstract: The authors discuss the manual production of a contiguous isodensity map or area cartogram. 3 aspects of the isodensity mapping problem were found to have a considerable bearing on both the viability of a manual solution and on the readability of the final map. These included the selection of a hierarchy of shape priorities to enhance readability, the determination of a plottable error for areas to decrease production time, and the actual construction procedure used. -Authors
Index Keywords: cartogram; contiguous; error; readability; shape priorities

Title: Digital geometric picture correction using a piecewise zero - order transformation
Affiliations: Department of Geography, Faculty of Environmental Studies, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, Ont., Canada
Authors with affiliations: Steiner, D., Department of Geography, Faculty of Environmental Studies, University of Waterloo, Waterloo, Ont., Canada
Abstract: This paper describes a procedure for the digital geometric registration of digitized air photographic data. Match points are located visually and used to formulate a global linear conformal transformation for each slave picture. Each transformation then serves to segment the corresponding image into regions such that, for the implementation of the correction, all pixels within a region can be shifted by the same number of rows and columns. In other words, the actual correction is achieved by a series of local translations (zero-order transformations). Remaining problems are then the filling of holes in the output pictures and the finding of a common submatrix. The image registration which results, provides a preprocessing operation needed to combine data from multitemporal and multispectral photography. © 1974.
Index Keywords: DATA PROCESSING; PHOTOGRAMMETRY; IMAGE PROCESSING; REMOTE SENSING; MAPS AND MAPPING

Title: Discrete data smoothing by spline interpolation with application to initial geometry of cable nets
Source title: Computer Methods in Applied Mechanics and Engineering
Affiliations: Institut für Statik und Dynamik der Luft- und Raumfahrtkonstruktionen, Universität Stuttgart, Germany
Authors with affiliations: Knudson, W., Institut für Statik und Dynamik der Luft- und Raumfahrtkonstruktionen, Universität Stuttgart, Germany; Nagy, D., Institut für Statik und Dynamik der Luft- und Raumfahrtkonstruktionen, Universität Stuttgart, Germany
Abstract: The problem of smooth-surface approximation from discrete data values is discussed. For the particular interpolation requirements of the cable net generation problem, a method of polar-coordinate smoothing spline functions is developed. Next a Newton-iterative method of automatic equal mesh generation is developed which uses the polar spline representation of the cable net surface. This method produces complete specification of the cable grid node locations and cable segments, including the irregular-length grid elements intersecting the net edge cables. Examples are presented to illustrate how the interpolation procedure functions and how the mesh generation procedure couples with the surface interpolation procedure to produce a satisfactory complete initial geometry specification. © 1974.
Index Keywords: STRUCTURAL DESIGN - Computer Applications; CABLE NETS; MATHEMATICAL TECHNIQUES

Title: Qibla, and related, map projections
Affiliations: Geography Department, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA 93106-4060, United States
Authors with affiliations: Tobler, W., Geography Department, University of California, Santa Barbara, CA 93106-4060, United States
Abstract: The qibla problem-determination of the direction to Mecca-has given rise to retroazimuthal map projections, an interesting, albeit unusual and little known, class of map projections. Principal contributors to this subject were Craig and Hammer, both writing in 1910. A property of retro-azimuthal projections is that the parallels are bent downwards towards the equator. The resulting maps, when extended to the entire world, thus must overlap themselves. An unusual recent discovery from Iran suggests that Muslims might have been prior inventors of a similar projection, by at least several centuries. A later corollary by Schoy leads to a new "cylindrical" azimuthal map projection with parallels bending away from the equator, here illustrated for the first time.
Author Keywords: Azimuthal directions; Map projections; Mecca; Qibla; Retro-azimuthals
Index Keywords: Projection systems; Azimuthal map projections; Maps; azimuth; mapping

Title: A sine on the road to Mecca
On a mixed local-global error measure for a minimum distortion projection
Abstract: In search for the minimum distortion projection mathematicians and cartographers have described a great variety of map error measures used to construct the best flat representation of a given geographic area. Traditionally , these measures were related to the paramaters of Tissot's ellipse of distortion; therefore, they were infinitesimal measures. Only recently were the measures of errors in finite distances introduced in cartography in order to produce equidistant-like images. The mixed error measure (which combines the Airy's measure of deviations of Tissot's indicatrixes with the mean square measure of errors in finite distances) is proposed to derive the minimum distortion polyconic projection. Expressed as a 5th degree polynomial, this projection minimizes the deviations of Tissot's error ellipses from a unit circle, while preserving the geodesic distances between distinct points on the globe as much as possible. The resultant world map represents the best compromise between equal-area, conformal, and equidistant representations. The parameters of the optimal projection are given, and the operational procedure used to derive them is stated.
Index Keywords: Mathematical Techniques--Polynomials; Combination Distortion Measure; Map Error Measures; Minimum Distortion Projection; Tissots Error Ellipses; Maps and Mapping

Title: Cartographic grids from Iran: An early version of the Retro-Azimuthal orthographic projection?
Affiliations: Faculty of Geographical Sciences, University of Utrecht, Meidoornlaan 13, Linschoten, ES 3461, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Dekker, E., Faculty of Geographical Sciences, University of Utrecht, Meidoornlaan 13, Linschoten, ES 3461, Netherlands
Abstract: In this paper the cartographic grids engraved on two antique instruments from Iran for finding the sacred direction and distance to Mecca are discussed. It appears that these grids can be well explained in terms of the Mecca-centred retro-azimuthal orthographic projection described in 1968 by J.E. Jackson. In this projection the lines of constant latitude reduce to a set of ellipses with their major axes parallel to the equator and the lines of constant longitude reduce to a set of non-equidistant straight lines parallel to the north-south direction. It is shown that the curves actually engraved on the instrument conform to this projection and can be fairly easily constructed. This interpretation of the grids on the Iranian instruments stands in contrast with another explanation, recently proposed by King (1999), which is based on medieval Arabic concepts such as the so-called 'method of the zijes'. Insufficiently accurate workmanship makes it impossible to distinguish between the two explanations through the study of the instruments themselves. The newly gained insight into the projection itself, however, shows that a direct relation between the Iranian maps and Islamic mappings known from the ninth century, as suggested by King, does not exist. Thus, it is concluded that it is as yet completely unknown when and where the very idea behind the Iranian cartographic grid was first conceived, and that the quest for their historical background is still open.
Index Keywords: cartography; historical cartography; instrumentation

Title: Calculating an azimuth from one location to another: A case study in determining the Qibla to Makkah
Affiliations: Saudi Arabian Cultural Mission, 99 Bank Street, Ottawa, Ont. K1P 6B9, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Almakky, G.A., Saudi Arabian Cultural Mission, 99 Bank Street, Ottawa, Ont. K1P 6B9, Canada; Snyder, J.P.
Abstract: For Muslims, the question of how to determine the azimuth or Qibla (Sacred Direction) to Makkah during the five obligatory daily prayer sessions is of great importance. Differences of opinion exist among Muslims as to how to calculate the azimuth from parts of the world not previously inhabited by Muslims, such as the continents of the Americas and Australia. Presently, there are two major and distinct points of view on this issue (Almakky 1994), each with a significant group of advocates basing its views on the Holy Qur'an (Koran) and the Hadith (prophet saying). One group believes in the validity of the rhumb line angle used in the world map designed by Mercator (so that the azimuth from the United States, for example, is towards the SE). The other group believes in using the great circle to determine the azimuth (in which case, the direction from the United States is towards the NE). In either case, the exact angle of the Qibla depends on the location of the person in prayer. This study describes a method that takes into consideration the actual shape of the Earth as well as the various approaches taken by Muslim scholars to provide an equation with which a person, regardless of location, can determine the accurate azimuth. This method uses a universal reference ellipsoid centred at the Earth's centre of mass to precisely determine latitude and longitude and uses trigonometric functions to compute the great-circle path.
Index Keywords: azimuth; cartography; ellipsoid; Makkah; Qibla

Title: Proximity matrix reorganization and hierarchical clustering.

Abstract: Connections between hierarchical clustering and the seriation of objects along a continuum that depend on the patterning of entries in a proximity matrix are pointed out. Based on the similarity between the central notion of an ultrametric in hierarchical clustering and what is called an anti-Robinson property in seriation, it is suggested that the two data-analysis procedures are compatible. -from Authors

Title: A World Map on a Moebius Strip
Conformality: Mathematical and Visual
Affiliations: University of British Columbia, Canada
Authors with affiliations: Mackay, J.R., University of British Columbia, Canada
Funding Details: Social Sciences and Humanities Research Council of Canada
Funding Text 1: For some mapping purposes, it may be just as desirable to have a map projection which has excellent visual conformality (i.e. , relatively small map areas visually resemble corresponding globe areas) as strict mathematical conformality. To this end, a study has been started, with financial assistance from the Canadian Social Science Research Council, to determine if it is possible to derive an expression by means of which the visual conformality of specified portions of map projections may be assessed. No attempt has yet been made to analyze the complex problems of visual perception; this aspect will be studied in cooperation with a psychologist.

Title: Population redistribution in the United Kingdom: internal migration trends in the 70s and 80s
Source title: Working Paper - University of Leeds, School of Geography
Affiliations: School of Geography, Univ. of Leeds, Leeds, LS2 9JT, UK, United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Stillwell, J., School of Geography, Univ. of Leeds, Leeds, LS2 9JT, UK, United Kingdom
Abstract: In 1988, a Limited Life Working Party on "internal migration' was established under the aegis of the Institute of British Geographers who recognized that the patterns and processes of migration within the UK, particularly flows between regions and labour market areas, were constituting an issue of major policy concern. The activities took two principal directions. The first involved a major review of progress made by recent migration research and an identification of the main challenges and opportunities which should be addressed over the next few years. The second utilised evidence from a variety of different information sources to provide an account of the dynamics of migration during the 1980s and, where more recent data was unavailable, of changes in migration occurring during the previous decade. This paper contains a selection of the findings of research conducted primarily by those members of the Working Party who contributed to the second initiative. The paper illustrates how the level of internal migration in Britain has fluctuated over time, identifies how migration propensities vary by population sub-group, demonstrates the changing geographical patterns of sub-national movement and presents a synopsis of regional perspectives. -from Author
Index Keywords: information source; internal migration; migration trend; population distribution; regional perspective; UK

Title: Pixels and Censels: Putting People in the Picture. Commission VII

Title: The traditional and modern look at Tissot's indicatrix
Affiliations: Intergraph Corp., One Madison Industrial Park, Huntsville, AL 35807, USA, United States
Authors with affiliations: Laskowski, P.H., Intergraph Corp., One Madison Industrial Park, Huntsville, AL 35807, USA, United States
Abstract: A new method of perception of Tissot's Theory of Distortions and the computation of the parameters of Tissot's Indicatrix, used to analyze map distortions of cartographic projections, is proposed. The new approach is based on the algebraic eigenvalue problem and makes use of the Singular Value Decomposition of the column-scaled Jacobian matrix of the mapping equations. The semiaxes of Tissot's Indicatrix are evaluated directly, and the usage of quadratic forms, which may cause unnecessary loss of numerical precision, is avoided. Several advantages of the new approach, versus the original Tissot's approach, are detailed. The traditional concept of Tissot's Indicatrix is also examined for comparison. -from Author
Index Keywords: cartographic projection; mapping equation; Theory of Distortions; Tissot's Indicatrix

Global digital vegetation and land-use data bases for climate studies.
Source title: Advanced technology for monitoring and processing global environmental data. Proc. RSS/CERMA conference, London, 1985, (Remote Sensing Society, University of Reading)
Affiliations: M/A-COM Sigma Data, NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Inst for Space Studies, 2880 Broadway, New York, NY 10025, USA., United States
Authors with affiliations: Matthews, E., M/A-COM Sigma Data, NASA Goddard Space Flight Center, Inst for Space Studies, 2880 Broadway, New York, NY 10025, USA., United States
Abstract: Global digital data bases of natural vegetation and land use were compiled at 1o latitude x 1o longitude resolution from over 100 published sources. These data bases were designed for use in a variety of climate-related studies (eg, surface albedo, surface roughness, biomass inventory and biomass change, net primary productivity, global modeling of trace gases) at global and continental scales. The 1o resolution of these data bases provides flexibility in aggregation to coarser spatial resolutions. In addition, the major benefit of the hierarchical classification schemes used in the compilations, ie, flexibility in both compilation and retrieval of data at various levels of detail, has allowed the derivation of a series of data bases tailored to individual applications. The data have been used independently, as inputs to both a 3-D general circulation model (GCM) and 3-D tracer-transport model, and as adjuncts to large-scale remote-sensing studies. -from Author

Title: Global land-surface data archives: comparison and application to climate modelling.
Source title: Advanced technology for monitoring and processing global environmental data. Proc. RSS/CERMA conference, London, 1985, (Remote Sensing Society, University of Reading)
Affiliations: Dept of Geog, Univ of Liverpool, UK., United Kingdom
Authors with affiliations: Thomas, G., Dept of Geog, Univ of Liverpool, UK., United Kingdom; Henderson-Sellers, A., Dept of Geog, Univ of Liverpool, UK., United Kingdom
Abstract: Until very recently land surface parameterization in climate models has been very poor partly because global-scale data pertaining to vegetation type and intensity and soil colour, texture and drainage were not available. Within the last four years at least five global-scale data bases have become available in computer compatible format and some of them have already been incorporated into general circulation climate models. These data archives differ significantly in resolution, source (satellite retrievals or atlas data), content and classification schemes employed. -from Authors

Title: ( Map transformations by computer-assisted techniques for the preparation of thematic maps). [Computer-unterstutzte Verzerrung von Kartenbildern bei der Herstellung thematischer Karten.]
Abstract: Transformations of the graticule are used especially for the preparation of city maps to extend the space for representations limited by the sheet size and the map scale. On certain premises such transformations are also suitable for the cartographic representation of thematic facts without special signs. By using computer-assisted suggestions for vector-orientated hardware the cartographic representation has to be digitized on a table digitizer, transformed and plotted on a vector-orientated flatbed- or drum-plotter. Both methods require an extensive preparation for the transformation process. A scanner can realize an important diminution of the digitisation time. -from English summary
Index Keywords: city maps; scale; scanner; transformations; vector orientated

Title: An integrated model of migration flows and population change for a system of UK metropolitan and non-metropolitan regions : a framework.
Source title: University of Leeds, School of Geography, Working Paper
Abstract: Outlines a framework for research into processes of spatial population change. Recent patterns of change for a 20 zone system covering the UK are described, and metropolitan non-metropolitan shifts are revealed to be much more important than N-S shifts. Levels of national and local mobility, age-group migration propensities and distribution patterns are described for the study set of zones. As a tool for consistent description and population projection, a system of populations accounts, accounts based models and data estimation tasks is outlined. Linked to this accounting framework are a set of alternative migration models.-Authors
